title: New Zealand election: National party's John Key claims victory â as it happened | World news | The Guardian
summary: labour leader david cunliffe concedes defeat .
`` the end of the mana party ''
national party wins more than 48 % of advance votes .

text: thanks for sticking with us for a historic night in new zealand politics .

here 's how it went down : prime minister john key 's national party has won a crushing victory in the new zealand parliament with 61 seats and more than 48 % of votes an increase on his 2011 winning margin .
key is expected to work with the act party , united future and the maori party to form the next new zealand coalition government .
labour leader david cunliffe has overseen a disastrous collapse in the labour 's party vote , winning less than 25 % .
cunliffe has said he wants to remain labour leader and take the government from the national party in three years ' time .
maori representation in parliament has been dealt a blow , with the maori party winning just two seats and the mana party 's leader , hone harawira , losing his stronghold of te tai tokerau .
pundits are predicting the mana party 's end .

kim dotcom 's internet party , which had banked its party 's hopes on a harawira victory , came away from today 's poll with no seats in parliament , raising serious questions over the upstart party 's future .
the conservatives have failed to garner more than 5 % of the party vote , which might mean the party win no seats in parliament .
winston peters ' new zealand first party has exceeded expectations , winning nearly 9 % of the vote , just short of the greens , who remained steady at 10 % .
however , pm key has indicated that he will not seek to include new zealand first and its raffish leader , peters , in a coalition government .
finally , deep thanks to our three assistants this evening , anna rankin , craig robertson and thomas carnegie , who provided local insights , context and good vibes throughout the night .
we could n't have run this blog without them .
craig robertson ( @ craigtrobertson ) 3,096,247 enrolled voters .
that 's a 76 % turnout .
# election2014 # decision14 that 's far from the record turnout we expected at the beginning of the night .
craig robertson ( @ craigtrobertson ) these are the 11 nz first mps that will be in parliament .
# election2014 # decision14
he brought a fortune , a global profile , and some stunning revelations - so why did dotcomb bomb ?

here 's geoffrey miller from otago university : kim dotcom spent almost $ nz5m of his personal fortune on a radical new left-wing movement which combined a new internet party with the indigenous mana .

it was touted as a strategic masterstroke - a way of exploiting a loophole under new zealand 's mmp proportional voting system to start a new grassroots political party which would turn out the youth vote .
it turned out to be - in internet terms - an epic fail .
not only did dotcom manage to fail to expand the vote , he ended up destroying the mana movement altogether .
unimpressed by hone harawira 's courting of a shady wealthy foreigner , voters in the northern maori seat of te tai tokerau rejected him in favour of labour 's kelvin davis .
by doing so , they wiped out the leftist mana party - quite possibly for good .
the dotcom debacle shows that while money can be important in politics , you can not buy elections .
even if harawira had scraped through , the paltry 1.3 % support for internet mana was scarcely more than mana had received in 2011 with virtually no money at all .
voters were turned off by the big money and the negative campaigning style of internet mana - which culminated in august with a video in which internet mana supporters chanted fk john key .
$ nz5m poorer , dotcom has nothing to show for his foray into politics .
it 's the dotcom bomb .
with 100 % of the votes counted , here are the final results from the 2014 new zealand general election .
final election results electoral commission

documents.title: john key claims momentous victory
text: key now claiming victory in a fairly dull speech .
this is for those who kept faith , he says , a victory for those who refused to be distracted .
win or lose , campaigns can be tough , and this was a tough one , he says .
key has also indicated that he will seek to form a coalition with some of the minor parties , despite his crushing victory .

mmp was designed to encourage parties to work together , so in the coming day i will talk to leaders of the other parties with a view to putting together a broader majority to ensure a durable and strong government , he says .
he signs off to a rapturous standing ovation , thanking new zealand - the finest little nation on the planet .
martin wehipeihana ( @ mwehipeihana ) like watching australia win rugby world cup # decision14
laura mcquillan ( @ mcquillanatorz ) the crowd 's chanting `` three more years ! ''

john key has just arrived at the national party 's official campaign event at the auckland viaducts , telling reporters as he entered , new zealanders knew this was their election , they wanted to own their election , they did n't want people interfering with that .
radiolive newsroom ( @ livenewsdesk ) john key makes his way into the viaduct events centre # decision14
antony green ( @ antonygreenabc ) the moment of truth - kim dotcom matches the electoral success of julian assange @ twitterid2014
sky news australia ( @ skynewsaust ) : cunliffe : `` have n't had time '' to talk to caucus to determine whether he still has their support .
# nzelections2014 # nzpol ( @ carsonscottlive ) labour leader david cunliffe has indicated that he 'll seek to remain at the helm of the party despite tonight 's shocking result .
sacha mcneil ( @ sachamcneil ) first to arrive & we 're the last to leave .
# tetaitokerau @ twitterid dire scenes from hone hariwara 's campaign party .
a mainstay of new zealand politics , hariwara lost his seat tonight to labour 's kelvin davis .
amazing scenes outside john key 's home , as he left to claim victory .
he was greeted by a group of young men from auckland grammar performing a spirited haka .
a haka greets john key as he leaves to claim victory john key watches on as auckland grammar boys perform haka

nicole bremner ( @ nicole bremner ) dotcom says he was reason for loss because his brand was poisoned for what they were trying to achieve it was n't broadcast , but kim dotcom apparently just apologised to the internet party 's gathering in auckland , but backed the future of the party .
no indication of whether they will continue to enjoy his financial support , which was worth $ 4m during this year 's campaign .

laila harre , the internet party 's leader , has just told 3news , clearly kim 's brand , kim dotcom , was a lighting rod for those who have been undertaking a campaign of vilification against kim for two years , and that made our new political movement vulnerable .
but she said his celebrity also brought many , many thousands of people into the party 's fold .

documents.title: labour leader david cunliffe concedes defeat
text: you are amazing , david cunliffe just told the labour faithful assembled in his electorate of new lynn .
you are courageous , you are hardworking , you are labour .
he conceded , we will not be able to form government even with new zealand first .
i 've called john key and congratulated him and acknowledged that he will continue to be the pm of new zealand at this time , he said .
it 's time to put aside political differences and work together for the good of this country .
cunliffe lamented a campaign beset by dirty politics and sideshows involving potential abuses of power at the highest level that will still take months and months to unravel .
he paid tribute to the formidable political machine of john key , which he said was disciplined in their messaging and their implementation - as someone from the crowd heckled , bloody media ! .
andrea vance ( @ avancenz ) `` you are amazing '' cunliffe tells the crowd .
have to say i do n't know why he is smiling so wide .

documents.title: why is key so popular ?
text: here 's our political analyst from otago university , geoffrey miller , explaining why the national party has been able to run away with the election tonight : there are three reasons why national is so popular : john key , john key and john key .
national 's leader is more than just the mastermind of a stunning landslide victory for the right .
he is a political phenomenon virtually without parallel .
john key has stared down a wave of attacks and scandal which dogged the party in the campaign .
but he has not just held the national vote or limiting its losses , but has taken the party to a result that he must not have predicted even in his wildest dreams .
third-term governments are meant to be cobbled together in weeks of arduous negotiations between friendly parties , not decided on the night .
why is key so popular ?
his common touch personality is part of it , but it 's far more than that .
key 's political antenna is razor sharp .

he had an intuitive feeling for what new zealand voters cared about in the campaign - economic growth , jobs and the rebuilding of earthquake-stricken christchurch - and stuck to those issues despite a wave of scandal .
national 's enormous result flies in the face of common wisdom .

the dirty politics scandal of underhand tricks from national 's more right-wing faction engulfed national a month ago , led to key effectively sacking a senior government minister , judith collins , just three weeks out from polling day .
and a week ago , edward snowden , julian assange and glenn greenwald revealed sweeping allegations of large-scale domestic and external spying by new zealand 's intelligence agencies .
but key , a former currency trader , knew that voters were more interested in new zealand 's fundamentals - essentially lower unemployment and a growing economy - than scandal .

do n't rock the boat was the campaign message - graphically illustrated by national 's main tv advertisement , which displayed national as a well-oiled team of rowers expertly cutting through the water .
the opposition was de as being lost at sea in a leaky boat .
national 's slogan during the campaign was team key .
it 's now key 's victory .

antony green ( @ antonygreenabc ) so national still on track for 61 seats in a 121 member house # nzvotes2014 if the national party manages to win that sum of seats , the question becomes whether they can govern in an absolute majority .
that depends on whether the nz parliament has 120 members in the next term or an overhang that would see extra members added .
the internet party leader is circumspect about her party 's poor showing .
is there any future for the internet party ?
that will emerge as a key question from this evening 's results .
laila harrã© ( @ lailaharre ) on my way into the cloud .
innovation and risk can not be separated .
maori party co-leader te ururoa flavell is greeted by tame iti at waiteti marae on in rotorua , new zealand .
ford/getty images

a comment from one of our readers below : it is intriguing that key appears to be pretty much the most popular and electorally successful political leader in the western world at the moment judging by this result .

where else , with a pr [ proportional representation ] system , would a leader be nudging close to 50 % of the vote after 6 years in power , mostly during a recession , and following recent scandals ?
true his support for same sex marriage suggests that he is a more intelligent conservative than many , but what else ?
any theories ?
agence france-presse ( @ afp ) # breaking new zealand tv networks call election for pm john key it 's beyond question now that key has won another term as pm .

what 's still up in the air is whether he can form government without entering into a governing coalition , which would likely include the economically dry act party and/or the nativist new zealand first .

documents.title: `` it 's all over for hone ''
text: 3news is calling the end of the internet-mana party , with hone harawira 900 votes behind labour 's kelvin davis with 86 % of the vote counted .

my colleague toby manhire has just filed his first take on tonight 's unprecedented result : the john key-led national party is poised to return to power in new zealand for a third consecutive term , having survived waves of scandal during a volatile and antagonistic election campaign .
with just over 50 % of the vote counted , national had received 49 % of the party vote , which determines the composition of parliament under new zealand 's proportional system .
the labour party trailed on 24 % , with the green party on 10 % and the new zealand first party , which had been as a potential kingmaker , on 9 % .
the rightwing family-values conservative party , on 4.3 % , looked unlikely to make the 5 % threshold that is required to enter parliament by any party without an electorate seat .

the internet-mana party , backed and bankrolled by german entrepreneur kim dotcom , was sitting on 1.3 % , well below the threshold but enough to bring in two mps should mana leader hone harawira hold on to his seat , te tai tokerau .
read the full story here

geoffrey miller from otago university on just how momentous a national party absolute majority would be : with 67 % of the votes now counted , it looks like the election is turning into a landslide victory for the right - and possibly even an absolute majority for john key 's national party .
this would be cataclysmic for the left .
polls showed labour would do badly , but few thought that the outcome would be so dramatic .
labour 's current support level of 24 % is dire , and at 10 % the greens have not met polling expectations of 12-15 % .
on the right , national 's current 49 % support level wildly exceeds the expectations of even the most optimistic right-wing pundits .
if it holds , national will not even need to consider coalition partners - because it will have an absolute majority .
this is huge .
under the mmp proportional voting system , which new zealand introduced in 1996 , no party has ever received an absolute majority of votes .

the closest parallel for what looks like a rout for the left is national 's record low of 21 % in 2002 , but even then labour did not receive an absolute majority - with voters flocking to smaller parties instead - and labour leader helen clark was forced to still cobble together a coalition .
there are still some caveats to apparent national landslide - we still need to wait for overseas votes and special votes .
and some of the polling booths which most favour the left are usually in the poorer south auckland area , and these are usually last to be counted .
but even taking these reservations into account , a comeback from the left at this stage is all but impossible .
this is a thumping victory for the right and nothing short of a triumph for national and john key .
new zealand prime minister and leader of the national party john key buys a sausage after casting his vote on the day of the national election in auckland on saturday .
phibbs/ap

documents.title: `` the end of the mana party ''
text: flicking over to maori tv for the moment , panellists are calling the end of the mana party following hone harawira 's disappointing showing in his seat of te tai tokerau .
harawira is currently being interviewed on the network , claiming there 's still hope , but his demeanour is pretty dejected .
interestingly , he 's wearing an aboriginal flag pin on his lapel .

antony green ( @ antonygreenabc ) labour on track for its lowest vote since 1925 # nzvotes2014 this is kiwis just being really content with where they are right now , says our election hq analyst thomas carnegie , sitting in front of a beer and satay chicken pizza .
let 's take a quick breath and recap on the evening so far .
prime minister john key 's national party is poised to win an absolute majority in the new zealand parliament with 62 % of the votes counted .
labour 's david parker says he 's disappointed with labour 's disastrous party vote , currently below 25 % far short of what the party would need to form a governing coalition .

maori representation in parliament could be dealt a blow , with the maori party set to win just one seat and the mana party 's leader , hone harawira , neck-and-neck with labour in his stronghold of te tai tokerau .
kim dotcom 's internet party , which has banked its party 's hopes on a harawira victory , looks set to come away from today 's poll with no seats in parliament .
the conservatives are currently tracking below 5 % of the party vote , which might mean the party win no seats in parliament .
winston peter 's new zealand first party has exceeded expectations , winning 9 % of the vote compared to the greens 11 % .
a key victory by this margin would be massive , especially given his scandal-ridden campaign .
nobody in new zealand has managed to win an absolute majority since the mmp system was introduced in 1996 .
3news is preparing to call the election .
rnz news ( @ rnz news ) hone harawira is only one vote ahead of his labour party rival kelvin davis .
# decision2014 # rnzvote the seat to watch is now te tai tokerau , on which the fate of the internet party hangs .
hone harawira is a mainstay of maori politics and has enjoyed a $ 4m injection to his party 's campaign from kim dotcom .
astonishingly , he may lose his seat .
one of the fascinating features of new zealand 's electoral system is that 7 seats in parliament are set aside for the country 's maori population .
the race for these seats is one of the most exciting to track tonight .

our otago university political analyst geoffrey miller has this to say : in recent elections , [ the maori seats ] have increasingly been won by smaller , maori-focused parties , rather than the traditional holder , labour .
this has led to what is called overhang - more than 120 seats in parliament because the maori and mana parties have won more seats than their party vote has actually entitled them to .
so the maori seats can affect the size of the new zealand parliament and the makeup of any coalition .
the maori seat most under scrutiny is te tai tokerau , north of auckland .
this is because hone harawira must win the seat for mana if the kim dotcom-funded internet mana project is to succeed .

if harawira wins te tai tokerau , internet mana gets an exception from the 5 % threshold rule and , on current results , has the hope of winning 2-3 seats - harawira and one or two others who are on the internet mana list .
but if hone harawira fails to win te tai tokerau , internet mana will end up with nothing .
mana party leader hone harawira chuckles as he prepares for a television interview at te rangi aniwaniwa school on saturday in awanui , new zealand .
rodger/getty images
di w ( @ di f w ) tonight i 'm realising i know absolutely nothing about nz politics .
i ca n't believe nzf 's vote is same as greens .
i just ca n't .
how how how .
there 's widespread astonishment at the strong showing by winston peters ' new zealand first party .

its name evokes shaved heads and jackboots , but i 'm assured that it 's more a populist nativist party , campaigning strongly on controlled immigration , better services for the elderly , and a crackdown on foreign investment .

the party leader , winston peters , has kicked up a stink about chinese investment in new zealand 's agriculture sector , reportedly quipping in august , as they say in beijing , two wongs do n't make a white .
when local media confronted peters on the joke , he said , the truth is the chinese guy in beijing told me that .
and he thought it was funny .
and i still think it 's funny .
however , my colleague thomas carnegie points out to me that most foreign money into new zealand actually flows from another source : australia .
so add buying up new zealand to australia 's list of trans-tasman sins , right under claiming phar lap , crowded house and russell crowe ( though i think we 're ready to give rusty back ) .
morgan godfery ( @ morgangodfery ) it seems hone will pull through and laila with him .
perhaps just .
it seems kim dotcom made a very poor investment .

# kåwhiri14 morgan godfery notes that hone harawira 's numbers have become stronger , but will only just pull through , despite the $ 4m contributed to his party 's campaign via the strategic alliance with the internet party .
toby manhire ( @ toby etc ) 614,322 of 627,577 counted so far are advanced vote toby manhire ( @ toby etc ) to clarify , so far more 95 % of votes counted were cast before today .
as we noted earlier , that would explain the enormous national lead ; pre-polling , which has traditionally compromised mostly rural voters , tends to skew strongly national .
how did an eccentric german internet entrepreneur named kim dotcom become so influential in new zealand politics ?

the new york times explains : the issue that has drawn international attention , however , has been mr. dotcom himself , who has become an outspoken character and a significant player in new zealand politics since he moved here several years ago .

born kim schmitz in germany before legally changing his name , mr. dotcom , 40 , is fighting extradition to the united states , where he is wanted on racketeering charges stemming from his file-sharing site megaupload , now defunct .
while out on bail as he appeals the case , he has introduced a new company , mega ; confronted the prime minister in parliament ; released an album ; and founded the internet party .

the party advocates decriminalizing marijuana , setting a national goal of 100 percent sustainable energy generation by 2025 , repealing surveillance legislation , and amending copyright laws to protect internet companies from civil liability arising from the action of their users , a fix that could shield hosting services like mega .
there is widespread sus as well , that if his party wins a place in the government , it will try to block his extradition .

read the full story here dotcom 's quixotic involvement in nz politics culminated on monday with an event in auckland called the moment of truth , where he dropped edward snowden 's revelations that the nz government had considered implementing its own domestic mass surveillance system .
it was intended to torpedo the campaign of pm john key .

however , as the front page of the new zealand herald splashed on friday , it appears that dotcom 's much-hyped revelations had backfired , with polls taken through sunday and monday showing that key 's ratings actually improved following the big reveal .
in this monday 4 august photo , indicted internet entrepreneur kim dotcom speaks at a political rally , in wellington , new zealand .
perry/ap dotcom is not running tonight because he 's only a new zealand resident and not permitted .
instead he 's designated himself party visionary .

and for my fellow australians , feeling smug that our kiwi cousins have allowed an eccentric plutocrat a seat at their national table , well , let me just leave this here billionaire mining magnate and federal mp clive palmer .
pickard/afp/getty images

documents.title: national party wins more than 48 % of advance votes
text: it 's not unexpected , but john key 's nationals have won a huge proportion of this year 's record advance vote .
worth noting is the relatively poor results of the internet-mana party , given the enormous emphasis they put on having their voters pre-poll .
advance votes electoral commission

morgan godfery ( @ morgangodfery ) hone looks like he 's in danger but wait for west auckland to come in # kåwhiri14 morgan godfery notes that hone harawira , the mana party leader , is struggling to win his seat according to early results .
that might doom the internet party , which has entered into a strategic alliance with mana , hoping that harawira 's success will propel its own candidates into parliament .
the second significant scandal to rock the national campaign , this one with international dimensions , is linked to revelations by nsa whistleblower edward snowden .

here how we reported it earlier this week : documents obtained by edward snowden , the nsa whistleblower , published on monday , revealed that the new zealand government worked throughout 2012 and 2013 to implement a domestic mass surveillance program .
codenamed speargun , the program involved installing cable access equipment to monitor the southern cross cable , which carries most of new zealand 's internet traffic to the world .
snowden wrote an accompanying post to the documents warning kiwis that he had been able to search their intercepted metadata while an analyst with the nsa .
if you live in new zealand , you are being watched , he said .
kiwi pm john key has acknowledged the existence of speargun , but said he raised concerns it was targeted too broadly and put a stop to its rollout in march 2013 .

the prime minister told radio new zealand on wednesday that new zealand intelligence did supply some information on individual persons of interest to the five eyes intelligence network database , but that it was not obtained by mass , whole surveillance .
you could not gather information about new zealanders without a warrant , key said .
five eyes is an intelligence-sharing alliance between the security agencies of the australian , canadian , us and uk and new zealand governments .

asked about snowden 's claim that kiwi metadata was accessible through xkeyscore , key said : i think the point he was making was , in that shared database , he said i regularly came across information about new zealanders ' that may well be right .
but he denied that new zealand intelligence was contributing that metadata .
we do n't have the capability for mass surveillance , he said .
read the full story here .

former national security agency systems analyst turned leaker edward snowden appears via video link from russia to hundreds of people in auckland , new zealand , town hall , monday , sept. 15 , 2014 .
phibbs/ap
here 's the nationwide party vote from tvnz , with around 18.3 % of the party ( as opposed to the electorate ) vote counted .
the nationals have shot to a significant lead ; also worth noting is the strong performance of the new zealand first party .
nationwide party vote
it appears to be a local tradition for the party leaders to feed the reporters covering their homes on election night .
john key fed the hacks pizza , david cunliffe provided sausages .
the greens have a vegan kitchen running ( with a taco truck mercifully parked out front of their election night function for the carnivores ) .
kate newton ( @ katenewtonnz ) pizza delivery man suneel poses with pm john key after delivering election night dinner
rnz news ( @ rnz news ) with 83.2 percent of advance votes counted - nat 48.4 % , labour 23.5 % , greens 9.9 % , nz first 9.1 % , conservative 4.4 %
toby manhire ( @ toby etc ) colin craig 's conservatives , sitting on 4.42 % , are going to tease us to the very end .
my colleague toby manhire notes that the conservatives are hovering around 4.42 % , with a quarter of votes counted .
they 'll need 5 % or their leader , colin craig , will need to win the seat of east coast bays .
he 's currently trailing by about 4,000 votes .
let 's deal with some of the controversies that have rocked this campaign .

first , an explosive tome by the investigative journalist nicky hager called dirty politics revealed that a senior national cabinet minister may have been involved in a smear campaign with a prominent right-wing blogger .

here 's more from my colleague toby manhire : hager draws on thousands of hacked emails and facebook private messages , which reveal [ blogger cameron ] slater 's links to jason ede , then a senior press adviser and so-called black ops co-ordinator in the prime minister 's office , as well as to senior cabinet minister judith crusher collins and others .

taken together , hager claims in the book , the material exposes the covert attack machine run by the national party and its allies and a new kind of attack politics ¦ rapidly changing the political environment .

he goes on : the national party has scrambled to explain correspondence suggesting collins , the justice minister and an avowed close friend of slater , had fed him with information about a public servant so that he could attack him on his blog , which led to death threats in the comments .

key , who earlier this year acknowledged that he regularly spoke with slater to see what he 's got on his site and mind , this week described collins 's action as unwise but refused to ask for her resignation , despite having given her a last chance after she was at the centre of political controversy earlier in the year .

read the full story here interestingly , source documents supporting hager 's claims have been drip-fed to the public by an anonymous twitter account , @ twitterid , which lists its contact address - in an homage to another famous whistleblower - as flat 3b , 3 hans crescent .
that would be the address of the ecuadorian embassy in london .
toby manhire ( @ toby etc ) with 11.4 % of party votes counted : national 48 % ( worth 61 seats ) ; labour 24 % ( 30 ) ; nz first10 % ( 12 ) ; green 9 % ( 12 ) via

documents.title: david seymour ahead in epsom
text: after 15 % of votes counted , act 's david seymour has a healthy lead in epsom .
as we noted below , that seat is crucial if the act party wants to have any presence in the next parliament .

documents.title: electorates to watch
text: craig robertson has compiled this list of three key electorates to watch : te tai tokerau the key electorate for kim dotcom 's internet party is the northern maori seat of te tai tokerau .
the party is in an alliance with the mana party .
both parties are relying on mana party leader hone harawira to defeat labour 's kelvin davis and win the seat .
the votes were close in 2011 , with harawira getting 8121 votes to davis ' 6956 .
epsom a key seat for national 's ally act .
the right-leaning act party relies on david seymour winning the seat of epsom to get into parliament .
act has a long-standing agreement with national to encourage voters to give their candidate vote to act and their electorate vote to national .
ohariu a key seat for united future 's peter dunne a coalition partner of national .
john key needs united future 's vote in parliament to prop up his numbers .
the votes were close last time , with peter dunne getting 14,357 , beating labour 's charles chauvel by 1400 votes .

documents.title: who 's who
text: from our special correspondents craig robertson , anna rankin and thomas carnegie : labour party a centre-left , socially progressive party .
it is new zealand 's oldest party and has traditionally been national 's main opponent .
national party a centre-right , socially conservative party ( with some non-conservative elements ) .
it is the largest party in parliament , and has traditionally been labour 's main opposition .
green party a left-leaning party established on principles of protecting the environment .
believes in investing in green technology , cleaner rivers and reversing the effects of climate change .
has been in opposition since 2002 .
internet party in alliance with the far-left-leaning mana party , the internet party was founded by internet entrepreneur kim dotcom .
believes in protecting privacy , internet freedom and investing in the digital economy .
mana party a left-wing party with a core focus on social policies and an emphasis on the treaty of waitangi as the basis of new zealand 's constitution .
seeks to be an independent maori voice in parliament .
aligned with the internet party .
conservative party right-leaning party established and bankrolled by businessman colin craig .
the party was established in the wake of the anti-smacking referendum with craig believing in the right of parents to smack their children .
believes in tougher penalties for crime , establishing binding referenda and flat tax .
has conservative social policies .
nz first a centrist-left party with a strong focus on immigration .
the party leader , winston peters , has worked with both national and labour in the past and is notorious for being the kingmaker in a number of elections .
the maori party a party based around new zealand 's maori minority .
it bases its policies on whanau ora ' an inclusive interagency approach to providing health and social services to build the capacity of all new zealand families in need .
it has a supply and confidence agreement with the national party .
united future a centrist party with liberal-democratic principles .
its policies are based on conservative family and social values .
it is in a coalition with national .
it relies on the ohariu electorate to get into parliament .
the act party far-right leaning party that focuses on individual choice and responsibility .
it believes the purpose of the government is to protect these rights and not assume such responsibilities .
the party gets into parliament by winning the very conservative and wealthy epsom electorate .
geoffrey miller , a political commentator from the university of otago , has offered these early thoughts , in which he says the conservatives are the party to watch .
all eyes will be on the performance of the new conservative party which is fighting to cross the 5 % threshold required to enter parliament under new zealand 's election laws .
the conservatives , who are headed by colin craig , do not have a realistic chance of winning an electorate ( constituency ( seat , for which an exemption is made under the 5 % rule .
so the only hope for the conservatives is to cross the 5 % threshold .
no public polls showed them making 5 % , but several had them very close in the lead-up to election day .
if the conservatives do make 5 % , then a national-led john key government is much more likely because no votes will be wasted on the right .

if the conservatives do n't make 5 % but come close , as expected , this not only leads to a large number of votes not counting , but also suggests that the conservatives ' main rival , nz first will have benefited .

nz first , led by winston peters , is competing for a similar pool of older , socially conservative voters , but has the advantage of being a more centrist party which can also win votes from the left .
so watch the conservatives - if they make 5 % , a right-wing government is very likely .
if not , then it may take weeks to find out who will be new zealand 's next prime minister - as nz first will probably hold the balance of power .
as we noted above , this election has seen record voter turnout .

this graph from the nz electoral commission shows just how remarkable the early voting has been : record early voting in new zealand 's 2014 poll electoral commission dr bryce edwards from otago university explain what it all might mean : those figures will be in early and give us a very strong view of the likely final result .
however , in the past such advance votes have favoured the right - so some caution is needed in overestimating national 's final vote .
this comes after years of decreasing turnouts , hitting a historical low in 2011 , edwards says .
but there 's every indication that there will be a large bump back up for this election .
large numbers of advance votes being cast are one indication of this .
but more than this , it 's been an incredibly colourful campaign that has ( unusually ) produced significant interest in politics .
no one in new zealand could be unaware that there 's an election going on .

documents.title: blackout lifted
text: here 's where each party roughly places on a left-right spectrum , from our special election hq correspondent thomas carnegie : thom carnegie ( @ tomcarnegie ) a well 'researched ' breakdown of new zealands political spectrum # elections2014 is he right ?
any changes .
let us know .
comments are now on .
so , how does it all work ?
new zealand 's election runs on a mixed member proportional ( mmp ) system , introduced in 1996 .
kiwis are given two votes ; one for the candidate standing their electorate , another for the party they want to support .
here 's how new zealand 's electoral commission explains it : the first vote is for the political party the voter chooses .
this is called the party vote and largely decides the total number of seats each political party gets in parliament .
the second vote is to choose the mp the voter wants to represent the electorate they live in .
this is called the electorate vote .
the candidate who gets the most votes wins .
they do not have to get more than half the votes .

under current mmp rules , a political party that wins at least one electorate seat or 5 % of the party vote gets a share of the seats in parliament that is about the same as its share of the party vote .
for example , if a party gets 30 % of the party vote it will get roughly 36 mps in parliament ( being 30 % of 120 seats ) .
so if that party wins 20 electorate seats it will have 16 list mps in addition to its 20 electorate mps .
coalitions or agreements between political parties are usually needed before governments can be formed .
it 's a little less dry when narrated by a giant orange man on video :
as a ty self-satisfied australian , my urge to mock new zealand 's election blackout law is as strong as the one to make tired ( but still hilarious ) references to sheep .
but earlier today on twitter , wellington-based writer giovanni tiso relayed this story from italy , which has a similar blackout law .
it 's worth sharing : giovanni tiso ( @ gtiso ) people influence people , and how influence works is not always obvious .
i 'm going to illustrate it with a little story about nuns .
giovanni tiso ( @ gtiso ) except this one time the supervisor of the polling place decided he was going to apply the law and not allow that to happen .
giovanni tiso ( @ gtiso ) so for a day we shut up , because if we keep talking it 's like we were walking into the booth with someone , sometimes .
the blackout is lifted in about 14 minutes .
here is international pop sensation lorde doing her civic duty urging young new zealanders to vote despite not being herself allowed to vote .
she 's 17 , one year shy of the legal age .
our team of experts , live from guardian election hq in auckland !
michael safi ( @ safimichael ) our special election correspondents

documents.title: election day blackout
text: here 's the front page from auckland 's biggest newspaper today : front page of nz herald herald notice anything strange ?
a curious provision in new zealand 's electoral act makes it illegal for media organisations to report anything that might influence voters until polls close at 7pm on election day .
the word influence is interpreted quite broadly , meaning any reference to a candidate 's polling performance , their policies , whatever , may wind up breaching the law .
this applies to any comments posted on twitter or facebook , so you can imagine it 's an unwieldy law to police .
nonetheless , according to the new zealand herald , individuals on facebook who hop on their political soapbox on the election day could wind up being contacted by authorities .
in a nod to sheer reality , the nz electoral commission says that websites are allowed to keep online any stories about the nz election written before polling day .
comments are supposed to be closed , though .
ours will open below at 7pm .
what is permitted , however , is photos of the candidates voting .
so here you go : the prime minister , john key , centre , with wife bronagh and son max cast their votes at parnell primary school , auckland , on election day .
setford/aap winston peters , the leader of new zealand first party , casts his vote on saturday .
dorday/ap the new zealand labour party leader , david cunliffe , casts his advance vote on 3 september .
robson/epa let us know if you feel influenced in any way and we 'll take them down .

documents.title: kia ora !
text: welcome to our coverage of the 2014 new zealand general election , beaming live from guardian election hq in auckland .
polls in new zealand opened at 9am local time and will close in about an hour , after one of the most extraordinary election campaigns in recent memory more on that later .
the country 's centre-right national party leader , john key , is seeking his third term as prime minister , after taking power from the centre-left labour party in 2008 .

fighting over the scraps are a bevy of minor parties including the greens , the mäori party , the mana party , new zealand first , the conservatives and an upstart new outfit called the internet party .
because of new zealand 's convoluted electoral system , these parties do matter , and have played a part in helping both national and labour form government in every election since 1996 .
we 're hoping to unpack each party below .

not to be outdone by the legion of guardian reporters that headed to scotland this week to bring you the referendum , this guardian outpost has assembled its own crack team to guide you through the results from decision 2014 .

i 'm manning our live coverage with the help of politics buffs anna rankin , thomas carnegie ( @ tomcarnegie ) and craig robertson ( @ craigtrobertson ) , who between them have 15 years of the finest undergraduate education new zealand 's tertiary institutions can offer .
out in the field is my colleague , toby manhire .
he 's written for the guardian extensively on the decision facing kiwis today and will file this evening as soon as a result is known .
dr bryce edwards , a politics specialist from otago university , will also be providing analysis throughout the next few hours .

inclement weather in parts of the country is expected to depress voter turnout , but the nz electoral commission today revealed that the number of advance votes - those cast before today - number around 717,000 , more than double 2011 's poll .
that figure represents as astonishing 23 % of enrolled voters .

according to the nz electoral commission , we can expect to know the results of that advance vote by about 8.30pm local time , with half of today 's voting booths expected to report by 10pm , and the rest 11.30pm .
do stay with us , and get involved ( nicely , please ) below .
tweet tips and abuse to @ twitterid we 'll be turning on comments as soon as new zealand law allows us , at 7pm local time .
a combo of file photos shows four of the major players in the new zealand election .
/afp/getty images

bulletin.text: New Zealand's prime minister, John Key, secures a crushing victory, following the most surprising election campaign in recent memory.
